title: Data Sources
text:
To thoroughly investigate the economic impact of the energy sector, this project utilizes a series of detailed datasets focusing on crude oil and natural gas prices, electricity costs, and key economic indicators. These datasets serve as the foundation for our analysis, enabling us to explore the intricate dynamics between energy market fluctuations and economic performance.

Crude Oil Price Summary (Table 9.1)
Source: U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)
Content: This dataset offers historical data on crude oil prices, capturing trends and volatility over time, which are crucial for understanding the energy market’s impact on the economy.
Application: We will leverage this dataset to analyze how crude oil price fluctuations correlate with economic indicators such as GDP and CPI, providing insights into the broader economic implications of oil price movements.


Natural Gas Prices (Table 9.10)
Source: U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)
Content: Contains historical price data for natural gas, illustrating trends and shifts in this vital energy source’s pricing.
Application: This dataset will be used to examine the trends in natural gas prices and their impact on the economy, particularly focusing on their influence on electricity pricing and economic indicators.


Average Prices of Electricity to Ultimate Customers (Table 9.8)
Source: U.S. Energy Information Administration (EIA)
Content: Details the average electricity prices paid by ultimate customers in various sectors, such as Residential, Commercial, Industrial, and Transportation.
Application: We aim to explore how fluctuations in energy prices affect electricity costs across different sectors, shedding light on the sector-specific economic impacts of energy price changes.


External Economic Indicators

GDP Data
Source: Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED), (Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis)
Content: The dataset provides data on the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), reflecting the economic growth and health of the nation.
Application: GDP data will be correlated with energy and electricity price trends to assess the broader economic impacts of energy market dynamics.


Consumer Price Index (CPI)
Source: Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED), (Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis)
Content: This dataset offers data on the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers: All Items in U.S. City Average (CPIAUCSL), which tracks the average change over time in the prices paid by urban consumers for a basket of consumer goods and services, providing a comprehensive view of inflation.
Application: Analyzing CPI data will help us understand the relationship between energy prices, inflation, and the overall economic condition, offering insights into how fluctuations in the energy sector influence consumer price levels.
By integrating these datasets, our analysis will provide a comprehensive view of the interconnections between the energy sector’s fluctuations and the U.S. economy’s health, contributing to the broader discourse on energy economics and policy-making.

title: Data Sources
text: The Six-Year Reviews are integral for maintaining the safety and quality of drinking water; by analyzing the compliance monitoring data from public water supplies, EPA assesses the occurrence levels, population exposure, and geographic distribution of regulated drinking water contaminants. This evaluation helps determine whether there is a meaningful opportunity to enhance public health protection by revising the existing standards.

title: Data Sources
text:
Six-Year Review 2 Contaminant Occurrence Data (1998-2005): This dataset from the second review (Six-Year Review 2) was reviewed in 2010, which included an assessment of 71 national primary drinking water regulations, is important for our historical analysis.
Six-Year Review 3 Compliance Monitoring Data (2006-2011): This dataset from the second review (Six-Year Review 3) provides us the second panel of the dataset from 2006-2011.

title: Data Sources
text:
In addition to the water contaminant data, we will be using colorectal cancer incidence data to explore potential correlations between nitrate levels in drinking water and health outcomes in California.

California Cancer Registry (CCR) Data (1988-2020): CCR provides comprehensive data on colorectal cancer incidence rates in California. This study will focus on data from 1988 to 2020, analyzing trends in colon and rectum cancer rates by sex, within the state. The long-term data will allow us to observe patterns and potential latency periods between nitrate exposure and cancer incidence.

title: Data Sources
text:
EPA: For the purpose of this study, we would extract and analyze data for California and only for the level of Nitrates in drinking water; the focus is on California, as it is one of the biggest states in terms of sample collection frequency. The combination of both the SYR 2 and SY3 data will help provide a comprehensive narrative by helping us examine any trend or seasonality in the dataset and further explore any potential correlations with health outcomes or regulatory changes.
CCR: Analysis will include a temporal correlation of nitrate levels from the EPA datasets with colorectal cancer incidence rates over the same periods.
The integration of colorectal cancer incidence data would enrich the study by enabling a multidimensional analysis of environmental determinants of health.

title: Introduction
text:
“To truly transform our economy, protect our security, and save our planet from the ravages of climate change, we need to ultimately make clean, renewable energy the profitable kind of energy.” – Barack Obama
In an era when the imperative of sustainability intersects with the dynamics of global energy markets, understanding the economic impact of the energy sector becomes crucial, and the statement by former President Barack Obama encapsulates the urgent need to transition towards a sustainable energy future, one that harmonizes economic growth, energy security, and environmental preservation. As the world grapples with the pressing challenges of climate change, energy production and consumption dynamics have emerged as a pivotal force shaping our economic landscapes.
In this project, I aim to delve deeper into the economic impact of different energy sources, exploring the intricate relationship between energy prices—specifically crude oil and natural gas—and their production and shedding light on the growing role of renewable energy and its impact on traditional energy markets. Additionally, investigating the relationship between energy prices and major economic indicators such as the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) and the Consumer Price Index (CPI), uncovering their ripple effects, if any, through the economic fabric.
By meticulously analyzing data from various sectors, including historical energy prices, electricity costs, economic indicators, and renewable energy production, this project aims to uncover valuable insights that could inform policy decisions, business strategies, and future research endeavors.


Before diving into the intricate details, it is essential to understand the broader landscape. This project aims to link the price dynamics of crude oil and natural gas with their effects on the economy, providing a comprehensive analysis within the global context. Understanding this bigger picture is crucial for grasping the multi-layered relationships between the energy sector and economic development.

This visual representation will serve as a guide through the thematic explorations of the project, setting the stage for a deep dive into the complex interplay between energy dynamics and economic indicators.



To navigate the complexities of how energy prices influence the U.S. economy, this project will dissect the data through multiple lenses, each offering a unique insight into the dynamics at play. The following analytical angles will structure our exploration:


We will examine the historical trends and volatilities in crude oil and natural gas markets. Understanding these patterns is key to grasping how energy costs affect the broader economy and to predicting future trends.



A critical angle is the relationship between energy prices and primary economic indicators—GDP and CPI. This perspective will allow us to measure the real impact of energy market fluctuations on economic health and consumer purchasing power.



As the energy sector evolves, so too does its economic impact. We’ll assess how the increasing presence of renewable energy in the national energy portfolio influences the traditional energy market and what that means for the future economy.



Different sectors respond to energy price changes in various ways. We’ll delve into sector-specific data, particularly focusing on how electricity costs for residential, commercial, industrial, and transportation sectors are shaped by underlying energy prices.



Energy policies can have a profound impact on prices and market stability. We will analyze the effects of past and present energy policies on market behavior and economic outcomes, offering insights into effective policy frameworks.
Each of these angles will be explored through rigorous data analysis, employing time series methodologies to unpack the intricate relationship between energy markets and economic performance. By examining these perspectives, we aim to build a holistic understanding of the energy-economy nexus and provide actionable insights for policymakers, businesses, and consumers.




The interplay between energy market fluctuations and economic indicators is a focal point of numerous studies, shedding light on how changes in energy prices influence economic growth, inflation, and regional development. This section integrates existing literature that provides the backdrop for our exploration of energy price impacts on the U.S. economy, with a particular focus on studies from the United States and China.
The report by the Congressional Budget Office titled “The Economic Effects of Recent Increases in Energy Prices” examines the response of the U.S. economy to significant energy price shifts from 2004 to 2006. Despite notable increases in crude oil and natural gas prices, the report finds that the overall U.S. economy exhibited resilience, with moderate impacts on GDP, employment, and inflation. This resilience is attributed to robust economic conditions, effective monetary policies, and increased economic flexibility and stability over the years. This study provides a crucial understanding of how the U.S. economy adapts to energy price fluctuations, offering a valuable perspective for our analysis. The graph below from this report illustrates U.S. spending on petroleum as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), showing that, despite fluctuations in energy prices, the overall economic impact has been moderate, though certain periods have seen significant spikes in energy spending relative to the nation’s economic output.

In contrast, Liping Wang’s study on “The impact of energy price fluctuations on regional economic development based on a panel data model” focuses on China, revealing the differential regional impacts of energy price changes on economic growth. Using data from 30 provinces and employing the FMOLS cointegration estimation method, Wang’s findings indicate that energy price variations, particularly in coal, electricity, and oil, have a tangible yet varying impact on China’s regional economies. The study underscores the significance of understanding regional disparities in energy price impacts, which could provide insightful comparisons for analyzing the U.S. context in our project.
These studies collectively enrich our investigation, offering comparative insights and methodological approaches to understanding the nuanced relationships between energy prices and economic indicators. By drawing on these studies, our project aims to dissect the specific dynamics within the U.S. energy market and its economic ramifications, enhancing our understanding and contributing to the broader discourse on energy economics.



The project is navigated by probing questions that aim to shed light on the multifaceted nature of the relationship between the energy sector and the economy. These questions will guide the exploration, analysis, and synthesis of findings, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of the economic impact of energy dynamics:

How have crude oil price fluctuations correlated with changes in the U.S. Gross Domestic Product (GDP)?
What trends can be identified in natural gas prices, and how have they historically impacted the cost of electricity for various consumer sectors?
In periods of significant oil price changes, how has the Consumer Price Index (CPI) reacted, particularly with respect to energy-intensive goods and services?
How do increases in natural gas prices affect the industrial sector’s energy expenses compared to residential and commercial sectors?
What is the relationship between crude oil prices and transportation sector electricity costs, and how does this relationship affect broader transportation industry economics?
Can we identify a lag effect between changes in crude oil and natural gas prices and subsequent adjustments in electricity pricing across different sectors?
To what extent do variations in crude oil and natural gas prices explain the year-to-year variability in the U.S. inflation rate?
How have renewable energy production trends influenced the electricity pricing strategies of utility companies in the residential sector?
During times of high volatility in energy prices, how resilient has the U.S. economy been in terms of maintaining growth and managing inflation?
What patterns emerge when comparing the cyclicality of energy prices with the economic growth cycles, and what might this imply for future economic planning and energy policy?




[1] Wang, L. (2022). Research on the impact of energy price fluctuations on regional economic development based on panel data model. Resources Policy, 75, 102484. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.resourpol.2021.102484
[2] Congressional Budget Office. (2006, July). The economic effects of recent increases in energy prices (Pub. No. 2835). The Congress of the United States, Congressional Budget Office. https://www.cbo.gov/system/files?file=2018-10/07-21-energy-dist.pdf
[3] https://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/monthly/
